section.heading: Purpose.
section.text: The purpose of the Patuxent Institution Youth Program is to provide remediation programs and services designed to meet the specific needs of eligible juvenile offenders and eligible youthful offenders adjudicated as adults.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Board of Review" means the Patuxent Institution Board of Review created by Correctional Servicces Article, §4-205, Annotated Code of Maryland.
"Commissioner" means the Commissioner of Correction or a designee.
"Director" means the Director of Patuxent Institution or a designee.
"Division" means the Division of Correction, which may include the Patuxent Institution Diagnostic Center Building or, during an emergency, other housing units designated by the Secretary.
"Evaluation team" has the meaning stated in Correctional Services Article, §4-101(f), Annotated Code of Maryland.
"Individual" means a juvenile offender or a youthful offender adjudicated as an adult.

"Inmate progress review" means the system by which Patuxent youth are assigned to Institution jobs, receive Institution job security classification, and are assigned to levels in the graded tier system, based on an evaluation of the security risk posed by the Patuxent youth and on the Patuxent youth's progress in Institution programs.
"Institution" means Patuxent Institution.

"Parole" means a conditional release from the Institution after a portion of the sentence has been served in confinement, with the balance of the sentence to be served under supervision in the community.
"Patuxent youth" means an individual who has met the criteria for admission to the Patuxent Institution Youth Program specified in Regulation .06 of this chapter.
"Program" means the Patuxent Institution Youth Program.

"Progress review committee" means a team of staff members, consisting of treatment staff from the inmate's treatment unit, a custody supervisor, and a member of the Education Department, who are responsible for assigning Patuxent youth to Institution jobs, job security classifications, and levels in the graded tier system.
"Remediation" means treatment for specific areas of mental and social deficiencies which are highly related to criminal behavior.
"Remediation plan" means a detailed treatment plan developed for an inmate by a treatment unit.
"Secretary" means the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
"Treatment unit" means a team of treatment personnel, which includes a psychiatrist, psychologists, and social workers, to which each inmate is assigned.
Except as provided in this chapter, COMAR 12.12.01—12.12.25 governing the Institution also governs the Program.
Parole is a privilege and not a right. Parole may be revoked in accordance with the procedures described in COMAR 12.12.13.03.
A court may, at sentencing, order the Commissioner to refer an individual to Patuxent Institution for evaluation, unless ineligible under Regulation .06 of this chapter, if the individual is:
Younger than 21 years old at the time of the referral; and
Sentenced to a term of imprisonment of 3 years or more for a criminal offense.
The Commissioner shall:
Maintain a list of individuals who have been referred by court order to the Institution for evaluation as participants in the Program; and
Submit the list monthly to the Director.
The evaluation team shall examine the referred inmate at either a Division facility or at the Institution. The Director shall select the location for the examination.

The evaluation team shall meet at the Institution to determine whether the Division inmate is a Patuxent youth according to the criteria in Correctional Services Article, §4-401(i), Annotated Code of Maryland, and Regulation .06 of this chapter.
If the examination is to be conducted at a Division facility, the following records needed by the evaluation team are assembled by the Division:
Documents from the base file as follows:
A copy of the commitment order,
The admission summary,
A copy of the sentencing guidelines,
Presentence investigation reports, parole reports, probation reports, and other reports that have been prepared concerning the inmate, or documentation that none exists,
Police reports and other relevant information concerning the crime for which the inmate was most recently convicted and the sentence imposed upon that conviction,
The State's version of the crime,
Prior criminal and juvenile history and all relevant records concerning it,
The disciplinary record, and
Correspondence from judges relating to their referral and recommendation of an inmate to the Institution;
School records;
The inmate's prior medical history, including the inmate's medical file and relevant medical and hospital records and reports;
The inmate's prior mental health history which includes:
The inmate's psychological file,
Previous psychological or psychiatric evaluations,
Record of psychiatric medications,
Progress notes, and
Records of previous psychiatric, drug abuse, or alcohol abuse treatment; and
Other relevant information, records, and reports concerning the inmate's social, physical, or mental condition and history.
If the examination is to be conducted at the Institution, the Division shall ensure that the records specified in §C of this regulation accompany the Division inmate to the Institution.
The evaluation team shall be provided the work space and resources necessary to carry out the examination.
After its review, the evaluation team shall develop a list of inmates in the following categories:
Patuxent youth who may be admitted to the Institution when Program vacancies occur; or
Non-Patuxent youth who may not be admitted to the Institution.

The evaluation team shall deliver a report to the Director recommending whether the inmate is a Patuxent youth or a non-Patuxent youth. The report shall support the team's findings with respect to the criteria set forth in Correctional Services Article, §4-401(i), Annotated Code of Maryland, and Regulation .06 of this chapter.
An individual meeting the referral criteria in Regulation .04 of this chapter may be admitted to the Program if the Director determines that the individual:
Has an emotional unbalance or intellectual impairment;
Is likely to respond favorably to the programs and services provided at the Institution; and
Can better respond to remediation through the services offered in the Program than through other types of incarceration.
Under the provisions of Correctional Services Article, §4-101(e), Annotated Code of Maryland, the following are ineligible for referral to the Institution for evaluation:
An inmate serving two or more sentences of imprisonment for life under the provisions of Criminal Law Article, Title 2, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland;

An inmate serving one or more sentences of imprisonment for life when a court or jury has found, beyond a reasonable doubt, that one or more aggravating circumstances existed under the provisions of Criminal Law Article, §2-303, Annotated Code of Maryland; and

An inmate convicted of murder in the first degree, rape in the first degree, or a sexual offense in the first degree, unless the sentencing judge, at the time of sentencing or in the exercise of the judge's revisory power under the Maryland Rules, recommends to the Commissioner that the inmate be referred to the Institution for evaluation.

section.heading: Treatment Programs and Assessment During Treatment.

para.text: A treatment program developed by the Director shall be governed by a set of clinical guidelines which include the specific:
Treatment methods to be applied within the Program; and
Outcome measures for determining the effectiveness of the program.
The treatment unit shall develop for each Patuxent youth an individualized remediation plan which shall:
Be approved by an Associate Director; and
Identify the specific therapeutic interventions to be used to address the inmate's remediation needs.
Assessment During Treatment.
The treatment assessment begins at the time a Division inmate is found to be a Patuxent youth and is transferred to the Institution for treatment.
The treatment assessment includes:
Comprehensive clinical reports;
Individual remediation plans;
Progress notes; and
Other information prepared by the staff for the Patuxent youth's annual consideration by the Board of Review.
Assessments are ongoing.
With the approval of the Board of Review, a Patuxent youth may be recommended to be continued in treatment or returned to the Division.
Inmate Progress Review.

The progress review committee shall review and decide the disposition of tier level demotions and promotions, job assignments, and job security classifications for each Patuxent youth assigned to the treatment unit.
Decisions of the progress review committee shall be by majority vote of the voting members of the committee present at the meeting.

A decision of a progress review committee that results in a change, whether positive or negative, in a Patuxent youth's tier level, job assignment, or job security classification shall be documented by recording on a progress review the:
Vote;
Supporting rationale; and
Dissenting rationale.
A decision of a progress review committee requires the Director's approval.
An affected Patuxent youth shall be given:
A brief written statement of the committee's decision; and
The reasons for the committee's decision.
The written statement may not reflect how the individual committee members voted.
Assignment of a Job Security Level.
The Institution is a maximum security correctional facility operated by the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
A Patuxent youth in the Institution's Program is assigned a security level for job assignment only.
For all other purposes, a Patuxent youth in the Institution's Program is considered to be a maximum security inmate.
Job Security Levels Available to Patuxent Youth.

Maximum. A Patuxent youth with this job security level shall be restricted to jobs done completely within the interior of the Institution's buildings. This classification shall automatically apply to all new arrivals to the Institution and remain in effect until revised by the proper action of the progress review committee.

Close. A Patuxent youth with this job security level shall be restricted to jobs that do not require the Patuxent youth to work outside the Institution's perimeter. Only Patuxent youth on third or fourth level tiers shall be granted close security unless otherwise authorized by the Director.

Status. A Patuxent youth with this job security level shall be allowed to work in jobs that require the Patuxent youth to be outside the Institution's perimeter under supervision. Only a Patuxent youth granted prerelease status by the Board of Review shall be allowed the job security level of status and automatically receive the job security level of status upon the Board of Review's grant of prerelease status to the Patuxent youth. A Patuxent youth on prerelease status shall retain the job security level of status while housed in the Institution.
The progress review committee shall consider the following in deciding whether to assign a Patuxent youth to a specific job security level:
Need for supervision;
Adjustment in the Institution;
Length of sentence;
Nature of the offense;
Progress in treatment; and
Therapeutic requirements.

At least annually and at any time at the Director's discretion, the Director shall review the Patuxent youth's continued eligibility for treatment or transfer to the Division based upon treatment staff recommendations. The Director, in consultation with treatment staff, security staff, or both, is authorized to remove an individual from the Program at any time for any reason.
The duration of incarceration of a Patuxent youth in the Institution terminates when:
The Director orders the individual transferred to the Division;
With the approval of the Secretary, the individual is ordered paroled by the Patuxent Institution Board of Review in accordance with the provisions set forth in COMAR 12.12.12; or
The individual's term of imprisonment is completed as provided by law.

An individual who is transferred to the Program in accordance with this regulation, following a commitment to the custody of the Commissioner, is considered committed to and remains subject to the Institution's jurisdiction.

An individual's transfer to the Program does not affect eligibility for diminution of confinement credits or other privileges available by law or regulation to an individual sentenced to the custody of the Division or a local correctional facility.

An individual released through application of diminution credits is subject to supervision by the Division of Parole and Probation and the authority of the Maryland Parole Commission, or by Patuxent Institution if clinically indicated.
